title: Brilliantly cinematic supernatural thrill ride Ghost Town is finally on PSVR 2 and it's easily one of my favourite games this year
text: It took about five seconds to figure out Ghost Town might be something a bit special when I first played it earlier this year. Before you even hit the 'start' option, you're transported to a dingy, moonlit South London car park in the driving rain. Fog drifts over litter-strewn tarmac, police sirens wail unseen in the distance, a concrete council block looms overhead, and just for a moment - even though I've not lived in London for over a decade - it felt a little like coming home. I've got a lot of good things to say about Ghost Town - it's easily one of my favourite games this year - but more than anything, its sense of time and place is utterly transporting. Read more

title: Nintendo Wins Latest Round In Its 15-Year Legal Battle Over The Wii
text: Nintendo has been known to vigorously defend its interests and intellectual properties in court, and one of its longest-running legal battles may be nearing its conclusion. In 2010, the Japanese video game publisher filed a suit in Germany against BigBen Interactive--the previous incarnation of Nacon--over its third-party Wii Remote controllers. Now, the latest ruling has unequivocally gone in Nintendo's favor. As reported by Games Fray , the Mannheim Regional Court has reaffirmed the ruling that Nintendo is owed damages of over €4 million plus interest. Because Nacon fought the ruling, that interest has increased the total fee to just under €7 million. Nintendo's contention was that Nacon's Wii Remote infringed on its patents for the sensor technology and camera needed to track player movements, as well as an acceleration sensor, and "the ergonomic features characteristic of Nintendo's Wii Remote." The initial verdict came down in 2011, but Nacon has consistently appealed the judgment and come up empty each time. Continue Reading at GameSpot

title: Arc Raiders Dev Looks Back On Game's Huge Launch, Says "The Work Is Just Beginning"
text: It's impossible to deny the success of Embark Studios' extraction shooter Arc Raiders . Now, as 2025 comes to a close, the studio is reflecting on the momentous launch, which was recently capped off by the title's win for Best Multiplayer Game at the 2025 Game Awards , and what's to come in 2026. If you're to believe Embark, which seems on top of the world right now, "the work is just beginning." In a post to Arc Raiders website , the shooter's executive producer Aleksander Grondal writes, "We had a feeling that Arc Raiders was something special. Internally, we were having a blast playing it before release, and your reaction to the tech test in April gave us an inkling of what was to come. What we didn't count on was the sheer scale of love and passion you guys were going to show this game." Arc Raiders, which was released in late October, became a smash hit right out of the gate, selling millions of copies within days and solidifying itself as one of the most-beloved multiplayer games of the year. Though many multiplayer games enjoy a surge of popularity that eventually relents, Arc Raiders has held on impressively long. As of this writing, its Steam numbers alone are still in the six-digit realm. Continue Reading at GameSpot

title: Dispatch Took "GTA 6 Amounts of Time" To Make, But Season 2 May Not Take Nearly As Long
text: Dispatch feels like the kind of game that must have always been headed for success, having sold a million copies in just 10 days , and while it missed most of the awards season, it still landed on several best-of lists for the year. That impression hides a much rougher reality. Dispatch took years longer than expected, nearly collapsed more than once, and only made it out because the team managed to survive long enough to finish it. "We're taking GTA 6 amounts of time on this shit," writer and co-founder Pierre Shorette says in an interview with Eurogamer , explaining why Dispatch Season 1 took so long to make. The episodic superhero workplace comedy spent close to seven years in development. The time spent wasn't about endlessly refining a hit, but about dealing with lost funding, shifting plans, and simple survival. The upside is that the groundwork is now done, meaning a potential Season 2 would not need anything close to the same amount of time. Game director Nick Herman is blunt about how close Dispatch came to ending. "We had a publisher who dropped us halfway through because of … financial things," he says. Shorette places that moment in the context of the wider industry collapse. Continue Reading at GameSpot

title: Redfall Boss Reflects On Game's Struggles And Studio Closure
text: Bethesda veteran Harvey Smith has reflected on the closure of Arkane Austin and the struggles of the studio's final game, Redfall. For anyone just catching up, Arkane Austin made the vampire game Redfall under Smith's leadership. After the live-service game failed to find an audience after launch in May 2023, Microsoft closed the studio a year later and ended most support for the game. Smith appeared on the My Perfect Console podcast recently and said ( via Eurogamer ), "Every company makes the decisions they make for the reasons they make them." For Arkane Austin's closure, Smith said the "shock" was that Arkane--as a wider group that also comprised Dishonored studio Arkane Lyon--made well-received and commercially successful games. Continue Reading at GameSpot

title: The Fallout TV Show Has No Todd Howard Cameos, And Here's Why
text: Bethesda's Todd Howard is the steward of the company's popular Fallout franchise, and many might have reasonably assumed he would have a cameo in the Prime Video TV show. He did not in Season 1 and does not have one in Season 2 , either. But why? Howard told IGN that he has been offered "a whole bunch" of cameo opportunities for the Fallout show, one of which was a doctor role at Vault-Tec. But Howard declined that opportunity and all others. "I think I'm best behind the camera," he said. Howard went on to say he's rejected all cameo pitches because he does not want to draw focus away from the storytelling, even if it would only be for a small moment. Continue Reading at GameSpot

title: Classic Final Fantasy Is Still Very Popular
text: Even after 30-plus years, the Final Fantasy games from the NES and SNES eras continue to stay in vogue. Square Enix has revealed that the Final Fantasy Pixel Remaster series has now surpassed 6 million copies sold. The official Final Fantasy account on X announced the sales milestone, thanking players for their support. The Final Fantasy Pixel Remaster series originally arrived in 2021, and at first, there was quite a bit of blowback for the font choices in the retro RPGs . The collection features remastered versions of the first six Final Fantasy games, starting with Final Fantasy on NES (1987) through Final Fantasy VI on SNES (1994). Updates for the titles include auto-battle functions and modernized UIs. The Final Fantasy Pixel Remaster series has sold over 6 million copies worldwide. Thank you for all your support, kupo! pic.twitter.com/1feTCfZrwj — FINAL FANTASY (@FinalFantasy) December 18, 2025 The Final Fantasy Pixel Remaster collection came to PS4 and Switch in 2023, followed by an Xbox Series X|S release in 2024. Overall, the Final Fantasy franchise has sold more than 200 million copies , as of March 2025. At that time, Square Enix noted that the Pixel Remaster series had hit 5 million copies sold, meaning the collection has sold another million units over the past nine months. Continue Reading at GameSpot

title: You Can Already Save 20% On The New Apple AirPods Pro 3

title: Blizzard's "Biggest Year Yet" Coming In 2026 For 35th Anniversary, President Says
text: Blizzard Entertainment president Johanna Faries has said fans of the Diablo and Warcraft company can look forward to what she hopes will be Blizzard's "biggest year yet" in 2026. 2026 marks the 35th anniversary of Blizzard, and Faries told Variety that the company has a "bold vision" for what's coming next. title: Baldur's Gate 3 Actor Sounds Off On Using AI For Voice Roles: "F**k AI In Performance"
text: Actor Neil Newbon, who voiced Astarion in Baldur's Gate 3, has shared his thoughts on artificial intelligence in gaming, and he didn't mince words. "Fuck AI in performance," Newbon told PCGamesN . He's talking about using artificial voice lines for games, like how Embark's The Finals and Arc Raiders do. For Arc Raiders, the studio hired human actors to record voice lines and then used AI systems to have their voices say lots of other things. Newbon pointed out that Arc Raiders has been a major commercial success, and he suggested that Embark bring back the actors to "redo the lines." Continue Reading at GameSpot

title: World War Z's New DLC Adds The Walking Dead Characters To Another Zombie Apocalypse
text: Two of the biggest zombie franchises are teaming up as World War Z's next story campaign DLC will cross over with The Walking Dead. Players will be able to take control of four of the iconic characters from the show--Rick Grimes, Daryl Dixon, Negan, and Michonne--with The Walking Dead stars Andrew Lincoln and Norman Reedus reprising their roles as Rick and and Daryl, respectively. The first trailer for the crossover should look very familiar to fans of both franchises. The new episodic campaign will unfold over three stories that revisit locations from The Walking Dead, including Grady Memorial Hospital, the Prison, and the Alexandria Safe Zone. But don't count on facing The Walking Dead's infamously slow hordes of walkers. This DLC is pitting the characters against a new incarnation of World War Z's Zeke swarms. There's also a fresh take on a Zeke called Spiked Walkers. This zombie is impervious to melee attacks unless it's been knocked over. However, the window of opportunity to take it out is short, and once it's back on its feet, it's no longer vulnerable. Continue Reading at GameSpot

title: Dragon Ball Daima Getting A Collector's Edition Blu-Ray Set
text: Dragon Ball: Daima - Collector's Edition $95 | Releases March 3, 2026 Preorder at Amazon Dragon Ball: Daima - Standard Edition $70 | Releases March 3, 2026 Preorder at Amazon The latest chapter of the Dragon Ball saga, Dragon Ball: Daima, wrapped up earlier this year, and it's finally coming to Blu-ray on March 3, 2026, just in time for the 40th anniversary of Dragon Ball. Like other high-profile anime series, you'll have the option to choose from two editions: a standard Blu-ray release for $70 or a Collector's Edition for $90 that comes with extra goodies. Preorders for both versions are available now at Amazon. Dragon Ball: Daima - Collector's Edition $95 | Releases March 3, 2026 The limited-edition version of Dragon Ball Daima includes all 20 episodes across four Blu-ray discs. While the on-disc extras include only clean versions of the opening and closing credit sequences, it also includes seven foil character art cards, a sticker featuring Goku, Vegeta, and Piccolo, and a silver foil rigid box with exclusive art by Daima's character designer, Katsuyoshi Nakatsuru. The illustration features Goku, the Supreme Kai, Glorio, and Panzy in the Demon Realm, while the rear shows off Kami's Lookout on Earth. Dragon Ball: Daima was well received when it launched, thanks to its back-to-basics approach, fluid animation, and answers to longstanding plot threads, making for a thrilling show. The 20-episode run also told a complete story, wrapping everything up nicely by the final episode. This was the final Dragon Ball project that its creator, Akira Toriyama, worked on before his death last year . Continue Reading at GameSpot

title: Sony’s Fight Against A Horizon Lookalike Has Come To An End
text: Following its decision to sue Tencent for creating a "slavish clone" of its Horizon games, Light of Motiram, Sony has concluded its legal battle with the company. The game is no longer listed on Steam or the Epic Games Store, and the court case has been dismissed. That's according to new court documents filed earlier this week, and Tencent added that it has reached a "confidential settlement" with Sony Interactive Entertainment. "SIE and Tencent are pleased to have reached a confidential resolution and will have no further public comment on this matter," head of communications for Tencent Americas, Sean Durkin, said to The Verge . Announced last year, Light of Motiram was quickly compared to Sony's Horizon series as it featured a very similar art direction and tone to the post-apocalyptic sci-fi series developed by Guerrilla Games. Both games featured vibrant environments and animal-like robots, and Sony was quick to file a lawsuit . Sony and Tencent eventually began discussions to resolve the dispute, with Sony demanding that Tencent pause all public promotion or testing for Light of Motiram. Continue Reading at GameSpot
